intro: Calophanoides hygrophiloides, commonly known as the water hygrophil, is a member of the family Onagraceae. It is a herbaceous annual plant characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, opposite leaves. The plant produces tiny, white to pinkish flowers that are typically clustered in racemes. It thrives in moist environments, such as wetlands and marshes, and is often found in tropical and subtropical regions. Its botanical features make it an important species for wetland ecosystems and ecological studies.
